description:
The image is a black-and-white illustration depicting Leonard Parkinson, identified as a Maroon resistance fighter from Jamaica around the year 1796. Parkinson is shown in a dynamic pose, holding a musket in his right hand and a knife in his left. He appears to be in motion, possibly running or advancing. His attire consists of loose-fitting clothing, including a sleeveless top and pants that are tied at the knee, along with a sash across his chest. His muscular build suggests he is physically fit and prepared for combat. The caption below the image explicitly identifies him as a Maroon resistance fighter, which indicates his involvement in armed resistance against colonial powers.

Maroons were communities of formerly enslaved people who escaped from plantations and formed independent settlements in remote areas. These groups emerged primarily during the era of the transatlantic slave trade when many enslaved Africans were brought to the Americas, including Jamaica. The Maroons fought for their freedom and resisted recapture, often engaging in guerrilla warfare against colonial forces.

Given this context, the historical development that contributed most to the formation of the society associated with the image is:

A. The Atlantic slave trade

This option directly relates to the origins of the Maroon communities, as it was the forced migration of Africans through the slave trade that led to the creation of these resistance groups. The other options do not have a direct connection to the formation of Maroon societies.
